synonyms: percutaneous vertebral augmentation, vertebroplasty, or kyphoplasty
anatomical location body part affected: Thoracic-lumbar  spinal column (can be at multiple levels)
description: Vertebral augmentation (V A) is a minimally invasive procedure using percutaneous injection of bone cement for rebuilding closed vertebral compression fractures. There are approximately 700,000–750,000  cases of vertebral compression fractures reported per year in the United States.(26,28)In most cases, V A follows several weeks of failed conservative treatment for unremitting pain, often in older patients with osteoporotic collapse of anterior body of vertebra(1) or in patients with cancer-related vertebral compression fractures(21)

V A attempts to restore the height of the collapsed anterior vertebral body and thereby reduce a kyphotic deformity(1) –In vertebroplasty, bone cement (typically polymethylmethacrylate [PMMA])(21,26)s injected, with a syringe, directly into the fracture site (usually anterior body) –In kyphoplasty, bone cement is injected into a cavity created with a balloon catheter,(2,3)which is proposed to increase vertebral body height and allow the PMMA to enter the space better(26) –When performed together, vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty are referred to as vertebral augmentation procedures(26) –Vertebral body stenting is a promising new minimally invasive V A procedure(4)

A newer technique called Kiva VCF uses a small spiral coil implant and reservoir to contain the bone cement(27) –In a 2015 randomized controlled trial, the Kiva Safety and Effectiveness Trial (KAST) compared balloon kyphoplasty with the Kiva coil and implant –Kiva was shown to be “non-inferior”  compared to balloon kyphoplasty in reducing pain and improving functional outcomes at 30 days, 6 months, and 12 months postoperatively –Of the 300 subjects, none reported complications due to cement

Interventions after V A may involve continued pain management; therapeutic exercise training to increase trunk stability, strength, and endurance; specific back exercises; and functional training to improve mobility, balance, posture, and gait
indications: To relieve back pain from osteoporotic or cancer-related  vertebral compression fractures

To reinforce the vertebral body in the presence of progressive spinal bone loss and lesions that weaken the vertebral body, such as in osteoporosis, osteolytic neoplasm, multiple myeloma, hemangioma, and osteomalacia
Based on the best evidence, V A should be limited to selected patients who fail conservative medical management(21)

Only about one-third  of osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures result in medical attention. Most are asymptomatic or result in mild acute back pain symptoms that respond to conservative treatment(21)
It is unclear which subset of patients with osteoporotic fractures benefit more from V A versus conservative therapy, based on a 2014 meta-analysis(18)

The patient population receiving V A typically has:(7) –failed to achieve satisfactory pain relief with conservative treatment –fluoroscopic evidence of vertebral compression fracture –continuing disability

Appropriate patient selection for V A, is based on clinical history, physical examination, and imaging that often includes:(21) –spontaneous collapse of one or more thoracic or lumbar vertebral bodies –collapse of anterior vertebral body that produces a wedge deformity and is associated with increased back pain and kyphosis, in most cases without new neural compromise (i.e., increased sensory deficits or motor weakness is uncommon) –low bone mineral density associated with osteoporosis –low-impact  trauma (e.g., fall from standing, riding in a vehicle over speed bump)

Increased prevalence of osteoporotic compression fractures is associated with:(5) –female sex –age 50 years or over –White or Asian ancestry –small skeletal frame with low body weight (under 127 pounds or 57.6 kg) –personal or family history of multiple broken bones –comorbidities with overall poor health and frailty –heavy smoking or drinking alcohol –long-term  corticosteroid use  –low-calcium  diet –prior vertebral fracture—once a vertebral fracture has occurred there is a 20% risk of another within 12 months(21)

ICD-10 codes.M80.8: osteoporosis with pathological fracture (vertebral column) (ICD codes are provided for the readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Depends on insurance contract coverage; no specific reimbursement issues are known regarding physical therapy after V A
presentation signs and symptoms: Most patients are older (> 65 years of age) women with spinal osteoporosis –History of persistent mid-back  pain despite conservative therapy (analgesic medications, spinal orthosis/bracing, activity modification, short-term  bed rest, physical therapy) –Sudden onset of localized, disabling mid-back  pain and increased kyphotic deformity, often with more than 6 cm loss in height, is indicative of acute vertebral compression fracture(5) -Increased difficulty standing, walking, and performing ADLs -Kyphotic deformity contributes to: -reduced mobility, rounded shoulders, forward head, decreased upper extremity ROM -decreased lung inspiratory capacity -malnutrition secondary to early satiety (i.e., kyphotic compression restricts abdominal volume) –Generalized weakness with muscle atrophy, especially after prolonged bed rest/inactivity –Loss of independence –Decreased balance secondary to change in the center of gravity. The patient may present with an assistive device, such as a walker, because of forward posture and fear of falling –Back pain

Signs/symptoms following V A –Significant pain relief, although underlying lumbar facet joint and/or sacroiliac pain can persist(6) –Tenderness and stiffness around surgical site –Improved mobility/physical function –Partial correction of kyphotic deformity Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications
contraindications precautions to test: Contraindications to evaluation include: –a lack of specific consent from the patient and referring physician to perform the back examination –inability of the patient to comprehend procedure because of cognitive impairment –unresolved inflammation, infection, or severe hematoma at the surgical site
Refer back to the physician if the patient presents with any symptoms indicative of potential cement embolism including: dyspnea, tachycardia, chest pain, hemoptysis, and cardiac arrest (33)
Stop the exam and notify referring physician in the event of red flags such as radicular signs of spinal cord/nerve root compression
Follow surgeon’s orders and protocol including any limits placed on spinal motion; clarify orders regarding examination procedures (including manual muscle tests)

overall contraindications precautions: Take special precautions to prevent falls, especially during functional training to improve posture, balance, and gait (e.g., use gait belt, parallel bars, or the assistance of another therapist as indicated). See  Clinical Review ... Falls in Older Adults  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708541
Select therapeutic exercises carefully to prevent activity-related  fractures, as the risk of bone fragility is high in this population
Avoid trunk flexion (e.g., sit-ups,  crunches, and other dynamic abdominal exercises) due to risk of osteoporotic spinal fracture
Exercise in patients with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is contraindicated until cleared by physician
Report any sudden increase in back pain or new back pain to the physician as it may indicate a new fracture
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: The mechanism of vertebral collapse is almost always related to bone loss in the vertebral body,usually due to osteoporosis

course of treatment.medical management: Document current medical management for back pain and comorbidities. What conservative treatments to improve mobility has the patient received? How did the pain respond to treatments? Did the patient require bed rest before V A, and if so for how long? Was a spinal orthosis prescribed?
surgical management: Surgical management:  What was the date of surgery? Which V A procedure was used? A new V A technique uses a KIV A implant for fresh osteoporotic vertebral wedge fractures.(19) Which vertebral level(s) received V A? How long was the hospital stay? When did the patient start ambulation? Were there any complications, such as local infection or bleeding, cement leakage, or spinal cord (rarely) or nerve root compression?
course of treatment.medications: Common analgesic medications prescribed for this condition include oral NSAIDs, including aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen, and meloxicam; topical NSAIDs (salicylate, diclofenac); and mild opiates (meperidine [Demerol], hydrocodone). Is the patient taking the prescribed medications? Does the patient feel they are effective?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Ask about pre- and postoperative findings on spinal X-rays  or other imaging studies for
osteoporosis testing, such as dualenergy  X-ray  absorptiometry (DEXA)
Patients with cement embolism are asymptomatic and therefore require chest radiographs to confirm it or rule it out(33)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Before the surgery, did the patient receive acupuncture, homeopathic treatments, or try spinal brace for pain?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient had preoperative occupational or physical therapy for back pain or other musculoskeletal conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Focus on the degree of postoperative back pain related to each factor and the time before the symptoms are aggravated or eased
history of present illness.body chart: What areas of the back are affected? Are the neck and upper back involved? Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms Associated symptoms -Numbness -Stiffness -Edema -Pain around the rib cage -Difficulty taking a deep breath -Neck or shoulder pain -Radicular signs/symptoms of compression of the spinal cord or nerve root
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. Specifically, address if pain is the primary symptom and whether it is present now and how much
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document whether there are changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (i.e., A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to spinal symptoms. Inquire about sleeping positions, use of pillows, type of mattress
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms that the patient may be experiencing, such as neck pain. Do these symptoms exacerbate the condition? Are these related to compensatory movements? Also document any symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician (e.g., bowel or bladder changes, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Does cognitive impairment limit the communication/education of the patient?
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise secondary to pulmonary restriction from kyphotic deformity?

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Are there other medical problems, such as degenerative disk disease, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, dementia, psychiatric disorders, or movement dysfunction? History of other pathological fracture (e.g., hip)? Does the patient smoke? Was the patient inpatient in the hospital before the surgery?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about the symptoms experienced other than back pain (e.g., groin, hip, or extremities)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient able to participate in desired occupational, recreational, or social activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Do symptoms interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Are there barriers in the home that restrict access such as stairs; are any modifications needed?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Is the patient underweight or overweight?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for ambulatory or adaptive device. If a device has been prescribed, is it appropriate and being used correctly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: There is no gold-standard  screening testA score below 45 (14 items, each scored on a 4-point  scale) is associated with increased risk of falling, with a sensitivity of 91% and specificity of 82%(9)More than 30 seconds is associated with the need for assistance with mobility tasks.(10) Twenty seconds or less is considered functionalA difference of less than 7 inches at loss of balance is associated with limitations in ADLs, balance, and mobility(8)Does the patient use proper body mechanics when performing functional activities or ADLs?
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses in lower extremities. Assess blood pressure in supine, sitting, and standing positions. Document symptoms of postural hypotensionAssess safety, ability, and need for adaptive equipment in general mobility. Assess level of assistance needed and the ability to log roll. Use FIM for objective assessment
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Note preferred walking speed, step length, step symmetry, and gait abnormalities (e.g., limp, shuffle, contact between swing foot and stance foot). A score of 22 or less on the Functional Gait Assessment (10 items scored on a 0 to 3 scale, 30 points possible) was found effective for classifying fall risk in older adults.(12)May also use the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) for gait assessment
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess the gross functional strength of upper and lower extremities, with special attention to quadriceps strength. Use manual muscle testing (MMT) in the absence of hypertonicity. Assess back-extensor  strength (prone or sitting position) by surgeon’s orders. Weakness in the spinal extensors may contribute to forward lean. Assess functional strength to lift, hold, and carry weights appropriate to patient’s age and ADLs. In a 2018 study conducted in Taiwan, the relationship between muscle strength and fall episodes among older adult community residents was evaluated. Authors found muscle strength, measured by average grip strength of both hands, was the most significant factor in one-year fall incidence with significant differences in hand strength identified among the fall group compared to the non-fall  group(13)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture in standing and for postural instability. Patients typically have a forward head position and thoracic kyphosis. Assess spinal alignment (posterior and lateral views) as well as the posture of the head, neck, shoulders, trunk, pelvis, and lower extremities. Is the kyphosis structural and/or postural? Forward head position and thoracic kyphosis contribute to postural sway. Is the pelvis rotated anteriorly and lumbar lordosis exaggerated? Are other spinal deformities present, such as scoliosis? Is there a leg-length  discrepancy?
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM of the thoracolumbar spine and, if involved, the neck, with careful regard to contraindications and precautions regarding spinal motion. Kyphosis typically restricts trunk extensionAssess ability to accomplish daily tasks
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisDefined as curvature of the thoracic spine measuring 45° or greater on X-ray.  Signs on inspection -head bent forward compared to the trunk (which effectively lowers the eyes) -may be restricted to the local area of vertebral compression fracture -patient unable to flatten kyphotic area with back hyperextension and scapular retractionDefined as correctable by the patient with coaching and responsive to exercises for posture re-education.  Patients may present with compensated postural kyphosis, as indicated by the anterior shift of the upper body above the site of V A(3)Anterior pelvic rotation may compensate for thoracic kyphosis, but it can lead to excessive lumbar lordosis and hamstrings contracture. Assess with Thomas or modified Thomas testA 10-item  questionnaire for the effect of back symptoms on ADLs

contraindications precautions: Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves, areas of diminished sensation, poor circulation, or slow-healing  wounds
Use caution with patients who are hypertensive, as cold can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; discontinue treatment if there is an elevation in blood pressure
Use caution with patients who are hypersensitive to cold
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Use of cryotherapy with patients who have an aversion to cold to promote muscle relaxation and decrease pain may be counterproductive
Stimulation through or across the chest
other: Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk(14)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment –medical referral for therapeutic exercise and functional training, to restore general physical functioning appropriate for patient’s age and comorbidities; improve posture, strength, flexibility, general mobility, and gait; reduce the risk of falls; and decrease residual pain –history of reduced mobility/ambulation –signs and symptoms of associated musculoskeletal pain –assessing response to rehabilitation program
prognosis: Functional mobility improves in most cases after V A(5)

In a 2014 study, vertebroplasty was found to decrease pain in 90% of patients, half of whom were pain-free  within 12 hours post-surgery(32) –The results were similar at the 24-month  follow-up.  At 2 years post-surgery over 80% of patients reported they were highly satisfied with the surgery

The evidence is lacking to favor V A over conservative therapy, either for primary outcomes (pain and disability) or secondary outcomes (quality of life, use of analgesics, etc.)(15)  –For example, a prospective study (N = 259) found no differences in outcomes for pain (V AS) or function (ODI) at 3, 6, or 12 months after balloon kyphoplasty vs conservative management(16) –In a 2017 meta-analysis  of 12 RCTs (n = 1231), authors evaluated the efficacy and safety of percutaneous vertebroplasty (PVP) vs conservative treatment (CT) in the management of osteoporotic vertebral fractures(15) -Outcome measures included pain relief using the visual analog scale (V AS) measured at one week, one month, 3 months and 6 months, quality of life measures including: the Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire (RDQ), EuroQol-5 dimensions (ED-5Q),  and Quality of Life Questionnaire of the European Foundation for Osteoporosis (QUALEFFO) and rate of adjacent vertebral fracture -Authors found PVP was associated with higher pain relief than CT at one week, one month, and 6 months and improvement in QOL as measured by the QUALEFFO. No statistical differences were found between groups at 3 months in pain relief, QOL measures on the RDQ and ED-5Q,  and rate of adjacent vertebral fracture
Positive functional outcomes of therapeutic exercise after V A depend mainly on exercise tolerance and adherence(16)
Strength training exercises are effective in reducing bone loss in the spine and wrist(11)
The risk of fracture in the adjacent vertebral body after vertebral augmentation remains controversial (2)

Authors of a retrospective study in China investigated risk factors and the incidence of new vertebral compression fractures (NVCFs) after V A (n = 290) compared toCT (n = 270)(34) –The investigators divided the patients into 2 groups (NVCFs and non-NVCFs)  and followed up on a monthly basis by telephone for 2 years. Authors found PVP did not increase incidence of NVCFs; osteoporosis was the primary risk factor for NVCFs

In a 2017 meta-analysis  that compared new vertebral fractures after vertebral augmentation or conservative VCF, investigators found no significant differences between the two intervention methods (35) –Risk factors for new VCF included low lumbar bone mineral density and total number of preexisting VCFs(2)

Although authors of a retrospective study in the United States found that post-V A fracture is not associated with different levels of physical activity, patients should be counseled to use extreme care when engaging in moderate physical activity(17) –Adjacent-level  vertebral fracture after vertebral augmentation can occur with osteoporosis, low bone mineral density, and with increased age(28)

A pooled analysis of published case series examining the efficacy of V A in patients with vertebral fractures due to multiple myeloma demonstrated that V A is effective in reducing pain scores and analgesic drug use(22) –The benefit was immediate and sustained for the duration of the follow-up periods (up to 4 years)

Based on a meta-analysis  of 27 studies of vertebroplasty or kyphoplasty for V A:(18) –Intervention within the first 7 weeks after the fracture may yield more pain relief –Spontaneous recovery may occur in fractures less than 2 weeks old –Patients with thoracic fractures or severely deformed vertebrae tend to report inferior results of V A

In a prospective study in South Korea that compared balloon kyphoplasty (n = 82) to conservative treatment (n = 149) for osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures, researchers found no significant differences in pain or ODI scores between groups at 3-, 6-, and 12-month  follow-up(20)

Authors of a 2015 study comparing vertebral compression fracture patients who received either balloon kyphoplasty or vertebroplasty versus no operation found decreased mortality and morbidity in the surgical patients(28)

Authors of a 2014 study of adverse effects found that 10.8% of 850 patients were readmitted to the hospital within 30 days after vertebral augmentation surgery. History of lung disease, smoking, and inpatient status before the surgery were found to be associated with readmission(29) –Thirty-day  mortality rate was found to be 1.5%, which is similar to rates for other spinal surgical procedures –No long-term  differences were found between vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician for medication review, especially if the patient is taking benzodiazepines, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, diuretics, or other medications that may cause dizziness or postural hypotension Physician, if vestibular disorders are suspected Pulmonary therapist if decreased respiratory function is noted with exercise therapy or ADLs Occupational therapist for assessment of performance-based  ADLs  Acupuncturist or pain management specialist for intractable pain
other considerations: Patients should be counseled to optimize medical therapy for osteoporosis prevention to reduce fracture risk
Adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D enhances the effectiveness of anti-osteoporotic  drugs and reduces fall risk(11)
Home assessment for fall-risk  factors and the need for assistive/adaptive devices as indicated
Transition to a supervised community-based  exercise program if appropriate for patient’s condition and approved by the physician
Exercises that improve balance such as tai chi can reduce falls in high-risk populations(11)

desired outcomes: Improved functional mobility/dynamic balance–Berg Balance Scale–TUG test–Functional Reach Test
Improved gait pattern with reduced fall risk–Functional Gait Assessment–6MWT

maintenance or prevention: Targeted back-extensor  exercises may decrease the risk of re-fracture(5)
A community-based  exercise program appropriate for older women may reduce risk factors for falls(11)
